title: How to Paint Laminate

steps.headline: Clean the surface using a trisodium phosphate mixture.
steps.description: Mix 0.25 cups (59 ml) of trisodium phosphate (TSP) with 1 gallon (3.8 L) of hot water to create a TSP solution. Dip a clean cloth into the mixture and use it to rub the area clean. Pay particular attention to any greasy spots. Use a clean cloth with water to rub off all of the TSP solution from the surface after you have cleaned away any grease and dirt. Purchase TSP from a hardware store. Be extremely careful when using TSP as it is a hazardous chemical. Always wear gloves when scrubbing with the liquid. Avoid getting the TSP on any surface except the laminate.

steps.headline: Sand the laminate using 150-grit sandpaper.
steps.description: Rub the sandpaper over the whole area using circular motions. Sand the area until the surface looks scuffed and has lost its shine. Stop sanding as soon as the whole area looks scuffed, as over-sanding can cause holes in the laminate. Clean the dust off the laminate surface using a clean, damp cloth. Leave the laminate to air-dry before applying the primer.

steps.headline: Cover any areas that you don’t want paint on with painter's tape and paper.
steps.description: Rip off strips of painter's tape and use them to cover any small areas that you don’t want to accidentally stain with paint. If there are large areas, use painter's tape to attach newspaper over the surface. Use an old sheet to protect the ground from paint. Purchase painter's tape from a hardware store.

steps.headline: Paint the surface with an oil-based primer.
steps.description: Choose an oil-based primer that is designed for shiny surfaces. Dip the bottom ⅓ of the bristles into the primer. Allow any excess primer to drip off the brush before you start painting. Start painting at the top of the area and work your way down to the bottom of the surface using smooth up and down brush strokes. Apply a thin and even coat. Purchase primer from a paint store.

steps.headline: Leave the primer to dry for 7 days.
steps.description: Keep the area free from dust by closing any exterior windows. This will help to avoid bumps forming on the surface of the laminate. The primer will take 7 days to completely cure and harden. Touch the primer to check that it isn’t sticky before you start painting.

methods.name: Painting Difficult Areas with a Brush

steps.headline: Choose a paint that is designed for the area you are painting.
steps.description: If you are painting laminate that will be exposed to lots of moisture, such as a bench top, you will need to choose a water-proof paint. For surfaces that receive a lot of wear and tear, such as floors or bench tops, a heavy-duty paint is a good option. When purchasing your paint, look for cans that advertise the qualities that you need. Acrylic paint is a good option for most furniture. If you are unsure of what color to paint the laminate, bring home a variety of paint swatches from a paint store. Place these on the laminate to help you decide which color looks best. Consider using a gloss or semi-gloss paint as these will make the surface easy to wipe clean.

steps.headline: Stir the paint using a wooden stirring paddle.
steps.description: Open the paint can using a 5-in-1 tool. Push the tool under the edge of the paint lid and use it to pry open the lid. Place the lid out of the way so you don’t stand on it. Use the wooden paddle to stir the paint in a circular motion. Continue mixing the paint until the colour is even and all the liquids are combined. If you cannot get the liquids to combine after 15 minutes of stirring, take the paint to a paint store and ask them to shake the paint for you.

steps.headline: Dip the bottom ⅓ of the brush into the paint.
steps.description: Place the bottom ⅓ of the bristles into the paint and push them against the inside walls of the can. This will push the paint into the brush. Gently tap the brush handle against the rim of the can, whilst the brush is over the can, to remove any excess paint. Use a paint brush that is suitable for the size of the area you are painting. If you are painting a small area, select a small brush. Use a larger brush if you are painting a large area.

steps.headline: Paint the corners and any hard to reach places.
steps.description: Use your brush to paint any places that will be hard to reach using a roller, such as corners and ridges. Use back and forth strokes to cover the difficult areas in a thin layer of paint.

methods.name: Using a Roller to Paint the Laminate

steps.headline: Pour the paint into a paint tray.
steps.description: Place your hands on either side of the paint can and carefully lift the tin over your paint tray. Gently tip the container and fill the bottom of the tray with 1 inch (2.5 cm) of paint. Place the lid back onto the paint can to keep the paint fresh. Purchase a paint tray at a hardware store or paint store.

steps.headline: Cover the paint roller with paint.
steps.description: Place the roller into the paint so that it sits flat in the tray. Roll it back and forth in the tray until the roller is evenly covered in paint. Tap the handle on the side of the tray to remove any dripping paint from the roller.

steps.headline: Paint the laminate using up and down stokes.
steps.description: Start painting at the top of your surface and work your way down to the bottom, this will help to stop any drips from causing bumps in your paint work. Use up and down strokes to cover the area with a thin coating of paint. Maintain a consistent pressure as your move the roller up and down the area. Paint over the areas you have already painted using a brush. Leave the paint to dry for 24 hours before applying further coats. Try to keep dust away from the wet surface as the paint is drying.

steps.headline: Apply 1-2 more coats of paint.
steps.description: Once the first coat of paint is completely dry, apply a further coat of paint using the same method as listed above. Let this dry for 24 hours before touching the paint. If the surface isn’t yet completely covered or isn’t as even as you would like, repeat the process of applying another coat of paint.

steps.headline: Leave the paint to dry for 1 week.
steps.description: Don’t move the laminate or place anything onto the painted surface for at least a week. This will give the paint a chance to cure properly. Placing pressure on the paint after a few days could put marks or dents in your paint-work.
